doc.label: Genome De-linked Annotation Viewer
doc.content:
GDAV

GDAV is a simple set of tools for publishing EST, gene or protein annotations on your lab or institution's web server. You may process, annotate and align your sequences in any way you like. GDAV just requires that you provide three simple file formats, each using the same sequence identifiers:

  1. One FASTA file of sequences (more)
  2. Tab-delimited file(s) of sequence annotations (more)
  3. GFF3 file(s) of genome alignments (more)

full details and installation instructions are available here

DAS

An optional component allows you to view similarities between your sequences and one or more genomes on your favourite genome browser (e.g. VectorBase) via the DAS protocol and the Dazzle DAS server.

Data sets served by VectorBase using GDAV

NameDescriptionData typeData sourceLink
Example/demo server Five Aedes aegypti sequences only! ESTs, nucleotide sequence N/A GDAV server
Anopheles albimanus ESTs (version 1) 3,252 clustered and orphan ESTs are annotated with InterProScan and BLAST and aligned to Anopheles gambiae. ESTs, nucleotide sequence Jesus Martinez, Institute of Public Health, Mexico GDAV server
Anopheles albimanus transcriptome (version 2) 16,669 assembled transcripts from Sanger, 454 and Illumina sequences, are annotated with InterProScan and BLAST and aligned to Anopheles gambiae and other species. ESTs, RNAseq, nucleotide sequence Jesus Martinez, Institute of Public Health, Mexico GDAV server
Anopheles gambiae mass spec. peptide data 120520 peptides originating from nine tissue and life stage samples. peptide sequences Raghothama Chaerkady, Johns Hopkins University GDAV server
"Next Gen" Expression data Interim provision of RNA-seq derived differential expression data. VectorBase transcripts Various research groups. GDAV server
Eight Anophelines mRNAseq contigs Assembled short-read transcript sequences for eight species which have no reference genome and therefore can't be displayed with the usual genome browser. transcripts Hittinger et al. GDAV server
Anopheles funestus mRNAseq contigs Assembled short-read transcript sequences for Anopheles funestus which currently has no reference genome and therefore can't be displayed with the usual genome browser. transcripts Crawford et al. GDAV server



GDAV is developed as part of the VectorBase project. Source and binaries are freely available under the GPL3.0 license here.

doc.label: Jacobina
doc.content: The Lutzomyia longipalpis Jacobina strain colony at the Liverpool School of Tropical Medicine was originally established by Richard Ward in 1988 by flies caught in Jacobina, Bahia State, Brazil and has been maintained continuously since establishment. At several times during this time, the colony has fluctuated in population size and has been expanded from a small number of flies.

doc.label: LlonJ1
doc.content: Three types of WGS libraries were used to produce these Lutzomyia longipalpis sequencing data: a 454 Titanium fragment library and paired end libraries with 3 kb and 8 kb inserts. The 454 data (11.5 million reads; ~24.4x coverage) was derived from the same individual while mate pair reads (7.4 million 3kb reads, 9.6X; 3.7 million 8kb reads, 4.9X)were derived from a pool of individuals. In total about 22.6 million reads were generating representing 38.9x coverage of this sand fly genome. The Llon_1.0 assembled draft genome sequence was built from the data described above using the Celera CABOG assembler (version 6.1, 2010/03/22). Next, these initial results were used as a backbone for longer superscaffolds using Baylor's ATLAS-link. Finally, discernible gaps filled with ATLAS-gapfill and ATLAS-gapmerge. The final assembly includes these superscaffolds, which can be ordered and oriented with respect to each other, and isolated sequences that could not be linked (single contig scaffolds or singletons from the original CABOG assembly). The total length of all contigs is 142.7 Mb; however, the total span of the assembly is 154.2 Mb after gaps are included. The N50 of the contigs is 7.5 kb and the N50 of the scaffolds is 85.1 kb. Both the assembly and the description of the positions and orientations of contigs (AGP) are available from the Sand fly section of the BCM-HGSC web site at: www.hgsc.bcm.tmc.edu. Sequence and Scaffold statistics: Scaffolds/Contigs Number N50(kb) Bases+Gaps(Mb) Bases(Mb) All Scaffolds 11,539 85.1 154.2 142.7 All Contigs 35,704 7.5 142.7 142.7 Deg Contigs 421,164 0.5 223.2 223.2

doc.label: Israel
doc.content: The Israeli strain of Ph. papatasi was originally was given to Walter Reed Army Institute of Research (WRAIR) in 1983 from the Hebrew University, Jerusalem. The population size of this colony fluctuated over time, experiencing several bottlenecks. The colony was expanded from a small number of flies at the University of Notre Dame.

doc.label: PpapI1
doc.content: Sequencing and assembly was performed by The Genome Institute, Washington University School of Medicine (St. Louis). DNA used for sequencing was derived from Phlebotomus papatasi females from the laboratory of Dr. Mary Ann McDowell, Eck Institute for Global Health, University of Notre Dame (Notre Dame, IN). These sand flies have been through several bottlenecks and were presumed highly inbred. All sequences were generated on the Roche 454 Titanium instrument with the exception of the BAC-ends, which were generated on an ABI3730. The Ppap1 assembly was built with the –het option, using the Newbler assembler test release 2.6RC02 from an input of ~22.5x total sequence coverage including 15.1X of whole-genome shotgun reads, 4.4X 3kb clone inserts, 3.0X 8kb inserts and 0.01X BAC-end read pairs. The fragment and 3kb data were generated from a single fly after whole genome amplification (WGA), while the 8kb and BES data were derived from multiple flies. All scaffolds larger than 200 bases (n = 123,558) total 347,840,937 bases with an N50 scaffold size and number of 23,692 and 2311, respectively. The longest scaffold was 2.04MB in length. Prior to submission to NCBI this assembly was screened for contamination and 247 contigs were removed. Additional contigs were removed or merged by the in house program PGA, PolyGraph Assembler, which collapses heterozygous contigs and reduced the assembled genome size from 410mb to 343mb. A total of 5661 gaps were closed and nearly 6.8mb of sequence was added by another in house post-assembly program, PyGap. This program detects and merges overlaps of adjoining contigs, and attempts to close gaps between non-overlapping adjoining contigs with Illumina data. The same Illumina data used in gap closure was aligned to the assembly to correct 89,378 presumed 454 insertion/deletion errors.

doc.label: Fasta file for GDAV
doc.content:
The fasta file should contain all of the sequences you have annotated. The format is as follows 

>ID1 description text
SEQUENCE...
>ID2 description text
SEQUENCE...
...

The ID format is flexible, but you are strongly advised to use GenBank IDs or some other public, linkable ID (so that you can link to an external database).

The description text is optional.

The sequence may wrap over several lines.

doc.label: TSV file for GDAV
doc.content:
These files contain the annotations for your sequences. These are simply tab delimited (separated) data where the first column contains the same sequence IDs that are used in the FASTA file you prepared.

The first line of the file should contain tab delimited column headings. These column headings are displayed on the annotation view web pages. The ID column heading can be anything, since it is ignored.

The example below uses spaces to simulate tabs, so do not copy/paste the example! 

ID      Length  Type
ABC001  100     EST
ABC002  123     EST
ABC003  999     cDNA

A sequence can have zero, one or more annotations in the TSV file: 

ID      Domain
ABC001  SH2
ABC001  SH3
ABC001  WD-40
ABC003  Ribosomal L8

You may load several TSV files from different analyses. These separate annotations will appear in different sections on the main sequence annotation view pages.

If you plan to link from a column to an external database, you should make sure than no other column has the same name. You can exploit this to create links to species-specific sites. For example you may have three separate TSV tables for BLAST best hits to species X, Y and Z. You should then name the columns containing the best hit identifier as "Best hit to species X", "Best hit to species Y" and "Best hit to species Z". Each column can then be configured separately to link to the appropriate species' website.

doc.label: GFF3 format for GDAV
doc.content:
This tab-delimited file should follow the GFF3 file format definition (see this page for a more lengthy description).

Extra notes/tips

There are no column headings in this file.

Column 1 should be the chromosome or supercontig name.

Column 2 should contain the name of the alignment algorithm you used (e.g. TBLASTX).

Column 3 should contain the type of feature: similarity, gene (for exons, see below).

Column 9 should contain Name=XXXX or Target=XXXX, where XXXX is the sequence ID (as used in FASTA and TSV files)

If you would like to display intron-exon structure via DAS, then you should create GFF3 file with parent/child relationships between exon and gene (or similarity) features as best described by the example below:

gdav-tutorial/example-data/gff3/Aedes5-vs-AgamP3.coding2genome.gff3 
3R      exonerate:coding2genome gene    33496909        33500187        16348   -       .       ID=gene000001;Name=TCLAA083948
3R      exonerate:coding2genome exon    33499973        33500187        .       -       .       ID=exon000001;Parent=gene000001
3R      exonerate:coding2genome exon    33498031        33499865        .       -       .       ID=exon000002;Parent=gene000001
3R      exonerate:coding2genome exon    33497644        33497952        .       -       .       ID=exon000003;Parent=gene000001
3R      exonerate:coding2genome exon    33496909        33497089        .       -       .       ID=exon000004;Parent=gene000001
2R      exonerate:coding2genome gene    54946304        54947673        6143    -       .       ID=gene000002;Name=TCLAA088857
2R      exonerate:coding2genome exon    54947523        54947673        .       -       .       ID=exon000005;Parent=gene000002
2R      exonerate:coding2genome exon    54947339        54947438        .       -       .       ID=exon000006;Parent=gene000002
2R      exonerate:coding2genome exon    54946304        54947258        .       -       .       ID=exon000007;Parent=gene000002
3L      exonerate:coding2genome gene    21659372        21661165        9141    +       .       ID=gene000003;Name=TCLAA104855
3L      exonerate:coding2genome exon    21659372        21661165        .       +       .       ID=exon000008;Parent=gene000003
2R      exonerate:coding2genome gene    51787946        51789994        7613    +       .       ID=gene000004;Name=TCLAA108437
2R      exonerate:coding2genome exon    51787946        51789994        .       +       .       ID=exon000009;Parent=gene000004
X       exonerate:coding2genome gene    11656322        11657470        7692    -       .       ID=gene000005;Name=TCLAA111852
X       exonerate:coding2genome exon    11656322        11657470        .       -       .       ID=exon000010;Parent=gene000005

Alternatively, you may provide a so-called cigar line in column 9 (Name=XXXX;Cigar=M100D20M200) - this reads from the 5' end of the transcript and describes the exon lengths (Mnnn) and intron lengths (Dnnn).

GFF3 from BLAST et al.

The search2gff script from the BioPerl distribution produces valid GFF3 from many database search program outputs, including exonerate and BLAST. Be sure to specify options "-v 3 -t hit" (and "-f blast" if using BLAST). For a full list of supported formats look for the file 'exonerate.pm' in your PERL5LIB path, then see the other files in that directory (e.g. sim4.pm, blast.pm). Note that NCBI TBLASTX does not produce gapped alignments or intron/exon modelling, so the alignments will be fragmentary.

GFF3 with intron/exons from exonerate

The GDAV utility script gdav-db-utils/utility_scripts/reformat-exonerate-targetgff-to-gff3.pl will produce valid GFF3 from the GFF2 output from exonerate (with --showtargetgff yes) when using the est2genome and coding2genome alignment models.

doc.label: GDAV help page
doc.content:
GDAV
GDAV is a simple set of tools for publishing EST, gene or protein annotations on your lab or institution's web server.

VectorBase's GDAV (Genome De-linked Annotation Viewer) is a simple set of tools for publishing EST, gene or protein annotations on your lab or institution's web server. An optional component allows you to view similarities between your sequences and one or more genomes on your favourite genome browser (e.g. VectorBase) via the DAS protocol. A list of live GDAV instances is available at the bottom of this page.

You may process, annotate and align your sequences in any way you like. GDAV just requires that you provide three simple file formats, each using the same sequence identifiers:

  1. One FASTA file of sequences (more details)
  2. Tab-delimited file(s) of sequence annotations (more details)
  3. GFF3 file(s) of genome alignments (more details)

GDAV was written by Seth Redmond and Bob MacCallum, with valuable input from Jesús Martínez Barnetche.

Contents

  • 1 System Requirements
  • 2 Annotate your data
  • 3 Download and unpack the GDAV package
  • 4 Build the MySQL database
    • 4.1 Create a brand new MySQL database
    • 4.2 Create the database table structure (schema)
    • 4.3 Preparation for loading data
    • 4.4 Load your sequences
    • 4.5 Load the alignments
    • 4.6 Load your annotations
    • 4.7 If you make a mistake
  • 5 Web applications
    • 5.1 Install GDAV and DAS
    • 5.2 Configure GDAV
    • 5.3 Configure DAS
    • 5.4 Testing
  • 6 Advanced configuration
    • 6.1 Indexing short words
    • 6.2 Changing the appearance of GDAV
    • 6.3 Multi-species GDAVs
    • 6.4 Gene-DAS source
      • 6.4.1 Welcome page
    • 6.5 Port 80

System Requirements

You will need a publicly accessible web server that runs Apache Tomcat, MySQL and Perl (with DBI drivers for MySQL). This should be relatively easy on both Windows and Unix-type operating systems. Also make sure that Tomcat and MySQL are started at system boot time to ensure continuity of service in the event of power failures etc. You or your system administrator should be aware of the security implications of having a machine on the public network.

Ask your system administrator to give you access to tomcat's administration web interface (http://your.server.org:8080/manager/html) so that you can restart web applications.

Annotate your data

How you annotate your data is entirely up to you, as long as you produce the three file types described above.

However you may find it useful to read about the simple annotation pipeline we successfully used on around 4000 Anopheles albimanus ESTs that we also aligned to the Anopheles gambiae genome.

Download and unpack the GDAV package

Download the latest version of the "binary" distribution: gdav-X.Y.Z.tgz (where X.Y.Z are version numbers) from this location.

As a normal non-root user unpack (tar xzf) gdav-X.Y.Z.tgz somewhere in your normal work area. This will create a new directory (gdav-X.Y.Z) which we will refer to as GDAV_HOME in these instructions.

Change directory to GDAV_HOME

Note: Everything in BOLD_CAPITALS in the instructions below should be replaced with something suitable for your particular installation.

Build the MySQL database

Ask your system administrator to create for you a non-root MySQL user with CREATE DATABASE privileges. From now on we will refer to this as MYSQLUSER (on MYSQLHOST, MYSQLPORT, using MYSQLPASS).

Create a brand new MySQL database

Think of a name for your mysql database. It must start with a letter, and contain only alphanumeric and underscores. Remember that appending a date or version number is always a good idea. The name will not be shown publicly. We will refer to it here as GDAVDB. If you are going to follow through all the steps using the example data provided, then we strongly recommend that you call your database example_gdav_db. This will reduce the amount of configuration editing later on.

% mysql -uMYSQLUSER -pMYSQLPASS -e "create database GDAVDB"

There should be no space between the -p and the password itself.

(Depending on your setup, mysql may also require host, port and socket options - these have been omitted for clarity. Check with your system administrator if you have problems.)

Create the database table structure (schema)

% mysql -uMYSQLUSER -pMYSQLPASS GDAVDB < sql/schema.sql

This wipes all data if the database already existed.

Preparation for loading data

To save a lot of typing set the following shell variable to contain the database connection options that the loader scripts require.

If your shell is 'bash', or you do not know which shell you use, then type (with your own username, password etc):

% dbopts="-dbuser MYSQLUSER -dbpass MYSQLPASS -dbname GDAVDB"

If your shell is 'tcsh' or you are using Windows (or if the previous command didn't work) then type:

% set dbopts="-dbuser MYSQLUSER -dbpass MYSQLPASS -dbname GDAVDB"

Check this has worked with:

% echo $dbopts

(As before, you may also need -dbhost, -dbport and -dbsocket options.)

In the sections below we will use the example data provided in the directory 'gdav-tutorial/example-data'. We recommend that you load this data first if you are not 100% confident with what you are doing.

Load your sequences

% perl gdav-db-utils/loader_scripts/load-seqs-from-fasta.pl -help
% perl gdav-db-utils/loader_scripts/load-seqs-from-fasta.pl $dbopts -species "Aedes aegypti" gdav-tutorial/example-data/fasta/Aedes5.fasta

In Windows the dbopts variable is written as %dbopts% and you may need to use backslashes (use this style for all subsequent commands):

% perl gdav-db-utils\loader_scripts\load-seqs-from-fasta.pl %dbopts% -species "Aedes aegypti" gdav-tutorial\example-data\fasta\Aedes5.fasta

Load the alignments

(Optional.)

% perl gdav-db-utils/loader_scripts/load-alignments-from-gff3.pl -help
% perl gdav-db-utils/loader_scripts/load-alignments-from-gff3.pl $dbopts -assembly "AgamP3" gdav-tutorial/example-data/gff3/Aedes5-vs-AgamP3.coding2genome.gff3

You may load further gff3 files if you wish.

Load your annotations

Load your annotation sets in the same order you would like them displayed on the web pages.

% perl gdav-db-utils/loader_scripts/load-annotations-from-tsv.pl -help
% perl gdav-db-utils/loader_scripts/load-annotations-from-tsv.pl $dbopts -description "InterProScan hits" gdav-tutorial/example-data/tsv/Aedes5.iprscan.tsv
% perl gdav-db-utils/loader_scripts/load-annotations-from-tsv.pl $dbopts -description "BLASTX best hit to AgamP3.4 peptides" gdav-tutorial/example-data/tsv/Aedes5-vs-AgamP3.4.blastx-best.tsv
% perl gdav-db-utils/loader_scripts/load-annotations-from-tsv.pl $dbopts -description "Cluster members" gdav-tutorial/example-data/tsv/Aedes5.cluster-info.tsv

If you make a mistake

It is probably easiest to start again with an empty database (reload the database schema). You shouldn't need to type everything again (your shell has a history!).

Web applications

Install GDAV and DAS

If you have not aligned your sequences to a genome assembly then you can skip the instructions for the DAS server.

Decide on a suitable name for your annotation web application. The name will be part of the URL of your new service, so think carefully. For example, versioned names, like 'albimanus-v01', allow you to keep multiple versions available in the future. From now on we will call this GDAV_NAME. (Note: if you already have a DAS server installed in tomcat please contact the VectorBase help desk for further assistance.)

As root or other adequately privileged user, rename/copy the following files into the tomcat webapps directory, WEBAPPS. On our system, this is /usr/local/tomcat/webapps

root% cp GDAV_HOME/webapps/gdav.war WEBAPPS/GDAV_NAME.war
root% cp GDAV_HOME/webapps/das.war WEBAPPS/das.war

OR, as a suitably privileged non-root user:

user% sudo cp GDAV_HOME/webapps/gdav.war WEBAPPS/GDAV_NAME.war
user% sudo cp GDAV_HOME/webapps/das.war WEBAPPS/das.war

After a few moments your tomcat server should unpack the .war files and start running the applications.

Configure GDAV

Tomcat should have unpacked WEBAPPS/GDAV_NAME.war to a directory called WEBAPPS/GDAV_NAME. If it has not, please talk to your system administrator.

Edit WEBAPPS/GDAV_NAME/gdav.xml
Change the <host> setting to the URL of your new GDAV_NAME web application.
Edit the MySQL database login settings in the <db> section. Don't forget to change <dbname> to the MySQL database name you chose (GDAVDB).
Edit WEBAPPS/GDAV_NAME/config.xml
<title> attribute: change the title that will appear in users' web browser window frames.
<col> attributes: customise the display/hiding of columns and link-outs from columns that contain external database IDs. Note that column names are case insensitive in this configuration file. The hyperlink and class elements are optional. The class option to set the CSS class of individual columns was introduced in release 1.2.0. Example <col> directive below: 
<col name="VectorBase transcript ID" display="true">
  <hyperlink>http://aaegypti.vectorbase.org/Genome/TransView/?transcript=####</hyperlink>
  <class>your_css_classname</class>
</col>
<alignSpp> attributes: customise link-outs from alignments to a genome browser. The "name" parameter is the same as the value you gave to the -assembly option of the load-alignments-from-gff3.pl script. If you aligned to more than one genome/assembly, you can therefore provide multiple <alignSpp> configurations to create the correct links for each genome.

Now you must restart the GDAV_NAME web application using the tomcat manager web interface or restart tomcat completely (the latter is sometimes required if you have unexplained problems).

Note: it is best not to hide columns (from the web display) that contain informative (and therefore indexed/searchable) text. If you do, people might not see the search terms they were looking for.

Configure DAS

Edit WEBAPPS/das/dazzlecfg.xml
If you are using the example data, then you simply need to edit the MySQL username and password, and the linkout URL.

Again you must reload the web application (das) using the tomcat manager or other means, for your changes to take effect.

Testing

Testing the annotation viewer
Point your web browser at the base URL of the web application, e.g. http://your.server.org:8080/gdav-example
Check the links and search box (you can search with annotation text, sequence IDs or sequence description text, try "elongation" or "IPR000795")
Testing the DAS server
Using the annotation viewer, view the annotation for a sequence that you know has an alignment to the genome
Click on the alignment location link (assuming you have set up genome browser links, see alignSpp configuration above)
In the VectorBase genome browser which appears, click on the "DAS Sources" menu of the "Detailed view" image panel.
Click "Manage sources"
Click on "Add data source" (top left)
Click on the "Enter server" button and fill in the URL of your DAS server: e.g. http://your.server.org:8080/das
You should see one (or more) available sources - select the one you want to view
Follow the instructions to complete the next steps - making sure to specify "Group features" = yes
When done, the contigview should reload and your DAS track should be displayed.
Check that the DAS track feature popups link back to your annotation server.

Note: To make it easier for your colleagues to set up the DAS track you can send them a single URL which does the whole job. This URL can be obtained by going to "Manage sources" again and clicking on the "mail envelope" icon next to your newly added track. You may also ask VectorBase to configure your track for all users (switched off by default) - please send your request using the contact form.

The authors' demo server (with the same example data used above) is here.

Advanced configuration

Indexing short words

By default the search facility will only work for queries of 4 or more letters. This is because the FULLTEXT indices in MySQL are configured this way. To change it, set the following in the my.cnf file for your mysql server. 

[mysqld] 
ft_min_word_len = 3

Restart MySQL and rebuild the indices on these three tables 

REPAIR TABLE annotation;
REPAIR TABLE model;
REPAIR TABLE submission;

Note that this will affect all databases on this MySQL server.

Changing the appearance of GDAV

You can change the colours in the stylesheet in WEBAPPS/GDAV_NAME/stylesheets/stylesheet.css

You can modify the layout and page content in the various .jsp files in WEBAPPS/GDAV_NAME and WEBAPPS/GDAV_NAME/includes - these files are basically HTML with some embedded Java. They are easy to edit if you know HTML.

So, for example, if you want to change the word "sequence" to EST you can do so quite easily (includes/menu.jsp, models.jsp, submission.jsp, submissions.jsp). If you make these changes, it is wise to make a copy before you upgrade GDAV - otherwise your changes might get overwritten.

Multi-species GDAVs

You can load sequences from several different species into one GDAV database, however you might want to configure a separate DAS track for each. Please use the optional "species" configuration variable (see the example dazzlecfg.xml file), to specify the species for each DAS source.

Gene-DAS source

We have implemented a Gene-DAS source for use with some interim RNAseq expression data at VectorBase. Here is the config for such a source: 

 <datasource id="nextgen_expression" jclass="org.vectorbase.gdav.dazzle.GeneSource">
 
   <!-- the following information is provided to people who are browsing DAS
        sources from your DAS server -->
   <string name="name" value="VectorBase "NextGen" Expression Summary" />
   <string name="description" value="Interim handling of quantitative expression data from RNAseq technologies." />
   <string name="version" value="default" />
 
   <!-- Change this to the URL of your gdav server.
        These are the links back from the genome browser to your annotations.
     -->
   <string name="linkout" value="http://funcgen.vectorbase.org/ExpressionData/NextGen/?m=" />
 
   <!-- Regexp defining which annotation sets to ignore -->
   <!-- e.g. ".*genes|.*transcripts" -->
   <!-- NOTE: the regexp has implied ^...$ -->
   <string name="excludeAnnotationSets" value=".*transcripts"/>
 
   <!-- database connection details follow -->
   ...


Welcome page

Simply replace the contents of "mainpanel" div of welcome.jsp with your own HTML content.

We suggest you include a short summary of the dataset (number of sequences, length distributions, description of methods, number of annotated/unannotated sequences, etc etc) and some links to example sequences and/or searches.

Port 80

Tomcat can run on any port, including the default HTTP port 80 which gives cleaner URLs. Your system administrator can move tomcat to port 80 if no other web server is running there. Alternatively, your existing Apache HTTP server can be made to forward traffic to tomcat on its usual port (usually 8080) with the ProxyPass directive. For example:

in tomcat server.xml 

<!-- Define an AJP 1.3 Connector on port 8009 -->
<Connector port="8009" protocol="AJP/1.3" redirectPort="8443" />

in apache httpd.conf 

<IfModule proxy_module>
  ProxyPass /gdav ajp://localhost:8009/gdav
</IfModule>

Remember to update the xml config files for GDAV and the DAS server accordingly if you change the outward-facing URLs of your services.

doc.label: GDAV Albimanus pipeline
doc.content:
This page describes the bioinformatics protocols used to annotate 3252 Anopheles albimanus ESTs by VectorBase and the Institute of Public Health, Mexico.

Contents

  • 1 Software used
  • 2 Analysis steps
    • 2.1 Input sequences
    • 2.2 EST clustering
    • 2.3 Genome alignments
    • 2.4 InterPro annotation
    • 2.5 BLASTX to proteomes
    • 2.6 NCBI link
    • 2.7 Cluster members
  • 3 Server configuration
    • 3.1 GDAV
    • 3.2 DAS server

Software used

You will need to install the following if you plan to follow our pipeline. (Please check the licensing for the following programs before using them.)

  • TGICL from http://compbio.dfci.harvard.edu/tgi/software/
  • InterProScan from ftp://ftp.ebi.ac.uk/pub/software/unix/iprscan/index.html (VectorBase may be able to run this for you, see below)
  • NCBI BLAST from http://blast.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/Blast.cgi?CMD=Web&PAGE_TYPE=BlastDocs&DOC_TYPE=Download
  • exonerate from http://www.ebi.ac.uk/~guy/exonerate/
  • GDAV's utility Perl scripts (in the gdav-db-utils/utility_scripts directory)

Analysis steps

Input sequences

We grabbed the sequences from EMBL/GenBank via an SRS query: 

Organism name = Anopheles albimanus
Molecule = mRNA

and exported a FASTA file. The IDs in this FASTA file were modified (with a Perl one-liner) so that they just contain a single GenBank accession directly after the '>', keeping the description, as follows: 

>EE284682 Aa-S7-001 Anopheles albimanus midgut Anopheles albimanus cDNA, mRNA sequence. 
AAGAAGTTCTCGGGCAAACATGTTGTGTTCATCGGTGAGCGTCGTATTCTGCCCAAGCCA
CAGCGTGGCAGCCGCGACCCYAACAAGCAGAAGAGACCGCGCTCCCGAACCCTGACCGCC
GTGTACGATGCCATCCTGGAGGATTTGGTCTTCCCGGCGGAAGTGGTCGGCAAGCGTATC
CGCGTCAAGCTCGACGGTTCTCAGCTGATCAAGGTGCACC
>EE284683 Aa-Sp14D2-001 Anopheles albimanus midgut Anopheles albimanus cDNA, mRNA sequence. 
CTGCGCGTGCCGGTGGTGGACAATGAGGTATGTGCCGATGCGTTCAGCTCGATACGGTTG
GAAATCATTCCCACCCAG

We did not trim the ESTs in any way, but this would improve the clustering (next step).

EST clustering

We ran tgi_cl on the fasta file with default settings. On 4000 sequences this takes a few hours.

After clustering we merged the cluster sequences (asm_1/contigs) with the unclustered singleton sequences (see TGICL documentation for more details).

All subsequent analyses are done on the merged file, which looks something like this: 

>DR748287 091_ANOPCA_P21 Anopheles albimanus adult female corpora allata cDNA library AN_ALBI_CALLATA Anopheles albimanus cDNA, mRNA sequence. 
ACGTAGCTGACCAAATATCTAGAGTTATACAACGACCCATTTTGCCTACAGTTCTAAGGT
CATCTGAAAAGAAATTTATCGGTATACGTAGGGCACACAGGATACAGGATACACATTGGA
GCGAACATGTTTTAGATGATCTATTGTCGGTTACTGAGTGATCAATAAAGAGCAAATGAT
AGAATAGCACCAACAGCATTAAGCAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAA
>DR748288 091_ANOPCA_P24 Anopheles albimanus adult female corpora allata cDNA library AN_ALBI_CALLATA Anopheles albimanus cDNA, mRNA sequence. 
AATGTTACTATAGTAAGGGTTTTTAGGTATACGTAGCTTAGGATGTCTTTTACTCTCTCA
TTCTTTGTCTACTTTCCGAGTTCTTAACCCTCTCTATGGGAAGGAATAATGGCGCAAAGT
GGTGGTCACAATAGAGTTGCGCCCAATCGTGCGCGTGCGACTGGAGGTGGGCGAGTGATA
GGAGCCGCGTGCGGTATTCGCCGCAGTAGCTAGTAGTAATCGTCGTTGCGGTTGTATCGT
TCAATGCAGCGGCATAGTAATGCAAATTCATGTAATTTTTTGAAAAGATCGAACAATAAA
CTCAACCAATTTTCGTCATCGCAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAA
...
>CL366Contig1
CGCTTAGGGGCGTTGTAGCAGGTACTTCTGCGCCGCACGCACTTGATCGAACGCCGATTA
TATTAGCATCCCTAACGTTAGATTAGTTTACTGATTTCACAGCCGTGTTTCATCGTTACA
TACATATATACTTTTCAAAATGAAAACGTTTAAAAGTTTTGTTTGGTTTTTTTTGCAGAA
TCGATATTCGCGTCAGCACTGCAAACTTTTATAGATTTTGACCCCCTCGGCTTCCAAATA
TAACATGCTATTGTTGCATCCTAACAGCACTTTCCTATAAGTTTTACTTGTATGTCTCCG
TTGCTTTTCACCCTCCCTTTCCACTGCAGCACTACTGTATGTACCTGCCCGGA
>CL367Contig1
AAATTGATGGGGTCTGGTAAAGAAATTTTGATTGAAAATAAAAAAAATAAAATGATTATG
GAATTGAGAAAAGAAAACAAAAATATTAAAAATATTAAAGAATCCTTTGTTGATGATTTC
CTATGATGAAAAGTAAATAAGAGTTAATATTTGTTTTATGGTTTATTTTAATAATTTAAT
AGGTTGAGATAAAAAATACGTTATTACTGTTATAAGATATTGGAAAGAATGATACTTGTT
ATGAATAAATCTACTGAAAATAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAGAAAAAAATT

Genome alignments

Here is one of 4 exonerate jobs that were run in parallel (--querychunkid 2-4 also ran). 

exonerate --querychunkid 1 --querychunktotal 4 --maxintron 20000 --softmasktarget yes \
  --model coding2genome --score 500 --bestn 1 \
  --query INPUT.fasta --target AgamP3_all_chromosomes_soft_masked_short_ids.fasta \
  --showtargetgff yes > EXONERATE_chunk1of4.out

This took about 2 days - you should consider using more chunks if you have more sequences or need results more quickly. Note that many of our parameter choices are species specific. After running several different configurations, we chose coding2genome because it produced meaningful alignments for more of our EST sequences (based on our observations on a set of immunity-related genes).

The target database is a soft-masked FASTA file (masked bases are in lower case) where the sequence IDs have been formatted as follows: 

>2L
..sequence...
>2R
..and so on...

These are the same chromosome IDs that are used in the VectorBase genome browser, so we can link to alignment locations easily (see GDAV and DAS config files at end of page). To create a soft-masked FASTA file from hard-masked and un-masked files (e.g. the two genome files available from VectorBase, you can use the fastasoftmask program from the exonerate package. Alternatively, just use the hard-masked file.

The output chunks can then be concatenated together and processed into gff3 with 

utility_scripts/reformat-exonerate-targetgff-to-gff3.pl EXONERATE_all_chunks.out > EXONERATE.gff3

InterPro annotation

Here is how we ran InterProScan 

iprscan -cli -i INPUT.fasta -o OUTPUT.raw -seqtype n -iprlookup -goterms -verbose -format raw

Note that this took a whole weekend on around 30 machines. Since VectorBase has it all set up to work with Imperial College's HPC cluster, we will run the InterProScan compute for you, resources permitting. Please contact the VectorBase help desk for more details (do not send the FASTA file yet).

Then we post-process the output to fix the first column IDs (when using translated nucleotide InterProScan), remove some non-specific annotations (Seg and Coiled coil) and to provide column headings. The output is GDAV-compliant tab-delimited text: 

utility_scripts/iprscan-raw-to-tsv.pl -ignore Seg,Coil OUTPUT.raw > interproscan.tsv

BLASTX to proteomes

Here is the commandline (run formatdb -i peptide_database.fasta first) 

blastall -p blastx -d peptide_database.fasta -i inputDNA.fasta -o BLASTX.out -b 1 -e 0.00001

Here is how we produced the .tsv table for the top hits 

utility_scripts/blastx-top-hit-to-tsv.pl BLASTX.out > BLASTX.tsv

This was done separately for A. gambiae, A. aegypti and D. melanogaster peptide sets (downloaded from VectorBase and FlyBase). For each output file, we edited the second column heading from "Subject" to "XXXXX best hit", replacing XXXXX with the relevant species name. This allows linking to the correct species website (see gdav config file below).

NCBI link

A trivial file like this: 

#id     NCBI link
AY955495        AY955495
DQ206710        DQ206710
DR747951        DR747951
DR747952        DR747952

allows you to configure links out to NCBI (see config file below).

Cluster members

utility_scripts/tgi-cluster-ace-to-tsv.pl tgi_cl_output/asm_1/ACE > cluster_members.tsv

Server configuration

GDAV

config.xml 
 <config>
        <!-- This will appear in the user's web browser title bar -->
 	<title>Anopheles albimanus EST annotations (release 01)</title>
 
        <!-- add an alignSpp block for each species/assembly      -->
        <!-- you are aligning to                                  -->
        <!-- the name refers to the assembly/species name you     -->
        <!-- provided to load-alignments-from-gff3.pl             -->
 	<alignSpp name="AgamP3">
 		<hyperlink>http://agambiae.vectorbase.org/Genome/Contigview?l=####</hyperlink>
 	</alignSpp>
 
 	<col name="interpro ID" display="true">
 		<hyperlink>http://www.ebi.ac.uk/interpro/ISearch?query=####</hyperlink>
 	</col>
 
        <!-- hide some columns -->
 	<col name="date" display="false" />
 	<col name="query start" display="false" />

doc.label: Welcome to VectorBase!
doc.content:
VectorBase is an NIAID Bioinformatics Resource Center dedicated to providing data to the scientific community for Invertebrate Vectors of Human Pathogens. We aim to provide a forum for the discussion and distribution of news and information relevant to invertebrate vectors, as well as access to tools to facilitate the querying and analysis of the data sets presented on this site.

DATA


GENOMES
TRANSCRIPTS &
TRANSCRIPTOMES
PROTEINS &
PROTEOMES
MITOCHONDRIAL
SEQUENCES

TOOLS & RESOURCES

COMMUNITY

Submit your data to VectorBase

VectorBase is not just for accessing data and using tools - we encourage you to actively contribute by submitting your own data and citations to enrich the knowledge base.
Publication
Submission
Gene
Predictions
Transcript or
Protein Data
Keep up with the latest debates or join the conversation by participating in community discussions on our forum, Facebook and Twitter.
', 'Tweets by @VectorBase ', $forumOutput); print($feeds[array_rand($feeds)]); ?>

doc.label: GDAV user guide
doc.content:
GDAV is very simple to use. Let us know if it is not (help desk). However, the search facility needs some explanation - see below.

Search

The following text is indexed (and therefore searchable) in GDAV:

  • ID of 'input' sequence
  • Species of 'input' sequence †
  • Description of 'input' sequence
  • Annotation set description (search will return all sequences annotated in that set)
  • Annotation values

†Any text word present in more than 50% of entries is ignored. Therefore for a single species dataset, species will not be searchable.

Search is case insensitive.

Searches for specific terms, such as IPR002048, AAEL012207 or ribosomal_l5 are most likely to produce meaningful results.

Multi-word searches are are combined with "OR" (not "AND" like Google and many search engines). Results are returned in order of relevance.

Wildcards and stemming are not currently supported.

doc.label: GDAV Anophelines pipeline
doc.content:
This page describes the annotation steps applied to the 8 assembled transcript RNAseq datasets from Anopheline species as described in this paper. This will closely follow an earlier protocol described for assembled Anopheles albimanus ESTs.

Software used

You will need to install the following if you plan to follow our pipeline. (Please check the licensing for the following programs before using them.)

  • InterProScan from ftp://ftp.ebi.ac.uk/pub/software/unix/iprscan/index.html (VectorBase may be able to run this for you, see below)
  • NCBI BLAST from http://blast.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/Blast.cgi?CMD=Web&PAGE_TYPE=BlastDocs&DOC_TYPE=Download
  • exonerate from http://www.ebi.ac.uk/~guy/exonerate/
  • GDAV's utility Perl scripts (in the gdav-db-utils/utility_scripts directory)

Analysis steps

Input sequences

Assembled transcript sequence FASTA files were obtained from XXXXXX for the following entries in the Short Read Archive:

  • Anopheles albimanus SRS008408
  • Anopheles arabiensis SRS008420
  • Anopheles dirus SRS008433
  • Anopheles farauti SRS008445
  • Anopheles freeborni SRS008481
  • Anopheles quadriannulatus SRS008482
  • Anopheles quadrimaculatus SRS008483
  • Anopheles stephensi SRS008484

The files have a consistent FASTA header of the following format 

 >SRS008408_74 Anopheles albimanus length=53 cov=347.075470

Genome alignments

Using exonerate, same command line options as in https://drupal2.vectorbase.org/content/gdav-albimanus-pipeline#genome_alignments

However, using exonerate 2.2.0, which has no memory leak issues, we found a problem with coding2genome (HSPs scoring < 0). Seems to be caused by short runs of stop codon matching at 3 of 4 codons. Have contacted author.

Found a temporary hack to fix this problem: in exonerate-2.2.0/src/sequence/submat.c change *,* match score in blosum62 from 1 to 2.


Issue - the input sequences are generally much shorter than we had before with Anopheles albimanus (not surprisingly, as this is next-gen). For example, previously we got 1500 alignments for albimanus, starting with 1800 seqs longer than 500. This data has only 266 seqs longer than 500 and we only get 256 alignmnents out in total. So we'll lower the score threshold to 200.

Interpro scan

Configuration:

Version 4.6
Data release 28.0
TMHMM version 2.0
minseqlen.aa 30
minorfsize 30

Command line example: 

iprscan -cli -nocrc -i Anopheles_dirus_contigs.fa -o Anopheles_dirus_contigs.iprscan.raw
        -seqtype n -iprlookup -goterms -verbose -format raw

BLASTX to AgamP3.6 peptides

Same options as https://drupal2.vectorbase.org/content/gdav-albimanus-pipeline#BLASTX_to_proteomes, using NCBI blast 2.2.16

doc.label: Moyo-S
doc.content: Sub-strain of the Moyo-in-Dry (MD) strain collected indoors from Shauri Moyo, near Mombasa, Kenya. Originally selected for Plasmodium gallinaceum susceptibility this strain shows an increased level of DENV susceptibility (~57% mean DENV serotype 2 infection rates). Used in studies in conjunction with the refractory Moyo-R sub-strain.

doc.label: Moyo-R
doc.content: Sub-strain of the Moyo-in-Dry (MD) strain collected indoors from Shauri Moyo, near Mombasa, Kenya. Originally selected for Plasmodium gallinaceum refractoriness this strain shows an low level of DENV susceptibility (~20% mean DENV serotype 2 infection rates). Used in studies in conjunction with the susceptible Moyo-S sub-strain.

doc.label: Configure this page @ the Genome Browser
Gene Predictions
doc.content:
You are encouraged to submit these types of data:
  • Gene structure information (both novel to VectorBase and corrections to existing models):
    • cDNA
    • Peptide
  • Gene name/symbol information:
    • Suggestions for names
  • Genomic sequence errors:
    • Assembly problems and sequencing errors
If available, you may provide:
  • Reference/citation details
  • Evidence for this submission (experimental and/or homology base)
Please use our Community Annotation Portal (CAP) for your submissions, and if you have any question please contact us .

doc.label: Transcript or Protein Data
doc.content:
You are encouraged to contact us with regard to submitting the following data for display on VectorBase:
  • Expression browser (e.g. microarrays and next-generation data)
  • Genome browser tracks (e.g. functional genomics and RNAseq data)
  • Annotated transcriptomes and proteomics data
  • Population and insecticide resistance data
Please note that we cannot promise to accommodate all datasets but we will try our best!

doc.content: VectorBase will have a booth at the ASTMH Annual Meeting being held from November 11 - 15 in Atlanta, GA.

doc.label: Anopheles gambiae male whole body (PMC3126782)
doc.content:
Chemosensory signal transduction guides the behavior of many insects, including Anopheles gambiae. To better understand the molecular basis of mosquito chemosensation transcriptome RNA sequencing (RNA-seq) was used to compare transcript expression profiles between the two major chemosensory tissues, the antennae and maxillary palps, of adult female and male An. gambiae.

Approximately 20 whole bodies of 4-6 d.o. adult males were collected. All collected tissues were immediately placed in RNA Later Ice (Ambion Corp.; Austin, TX) on ice prior to RNA extraction. Total RNA was isolated from each sample using RNeasy columns (Qiagen Inc.; Carlsbad, CA) according to the manufacturer's protocol. mRNA isolation and cDNA library preparation were carried out using the Illumina mRNA sequencing kit (Illumina Inc.; San Diego, CA). Libraries were sequenced using an Illumina Genome Analyzer II or HiSeq2000.

TGMA IDs:

TGMA:0001838 Male organism (whole body)

doc.label: Suakoko
doc.content: The Anopheles gambiae s.s. colony originated from Suakoko, Liberia (by courtesy of Professor M. Coluzzi, Rome).

doc.label: Rules and conventions for naming genes
doc.content:
Introduction

The rules for the genetic and molecular nomenclature of Anopheles gambiae and other anophelines were adopted by the International Anopheles Genome Executive Committee after the publication of the complete genome sequence data in Science (October 4, 2002 Vol. 298). Part of these rules was published in the supplementary material of the paper by Christophides et al. [(2002) Science 298: 159-165], while additional rules were adapted, in a simplified form, from those governing the nomenclature of Drosophila . Obviously, at this time the need for an all-inclusive catalogue of rules, such as the one set up for the fruitfly, is not an urgent one. This is the reason why the following list is much shorter. Should authors realise that they need more detailed instructions, they should contact the AnoBase curators ( AnoBase-comments@imbb.forth.gr) and discuss the matter. Authors are urged to use these rules when naming genes or other genetic structures to avoid unsystematic and duplicate names. In the future VectorBase will be curating gene names. Should a name be identified, which does not agree with the rules, the author will be contacted by VectorBase and alternatives will be suggested. In case of a continued disagreement, VectorBase will keep the "incorrect" name as a synonym, while a valid name will be assigned to the gene or genetic structure.

Genes

Gene names are to be modeled on those recommended by the Human Genome Organization (HUGO) for naming human genes. The rules are as follows:
  • The names are mnemonic symbols, designed for easy recall. They do not aim to summarize all current information (orthology, function, chromosomal location), which in any case is incomplete and subject to errors .
  • To avoid errors in electronic communication all names consist exclusively of capital letters of the Latin alphabet and Arabic numerals; no punctuation marks, dashes etc. are used.
  • Genes from anopheline species other than An. gambiae: To minimize the length the formal names do not include taxonomic initials. If similarly named genes of two organisms are being compared, taxonomic initials can be added for convenience, but do not constitute part of the name (e.g. aTEP to be easily distinguished from dTep). VectorBase includes genes from all anophelines. For species other than An. gambiae, the valid gene symbol follows a species abbreviation indicating the species of origin. The prefix has the form Nnnn\, where N is the initial letter of the genus (i.e., A for Anopheles, B for Bironella and C for Chagasia) and nnn is a unique code, usually the first three letters of the species name (e.g., ara for An. arabiensis). A list of valid species abbreviations is available in this ("Documents").
  • Roman letters and numerals indicate protein, italics indicate gene or RNA.
  • The name is based on sequence similarities and carries no functional implications, which must be determined experimentally.
  • The name consists of two to three contiguous fields, as follows:
    • The first field includes three to five letters and is an abbreviations of the highest sequence grouping used, usually a protein family, e.g. CLIP (for Clip-domain serine protease), or SCR (for Scavenger Receptor)
    • The second field, if present, includes one or more letters identifying a subgroup such as subfamily (e.g. CLIPD), or class (e.g. SCRB).
    • The third field enumerates each gene by using consecutive numerals (e.g. SCRB1,… 12). Sometimes the third field numeral can be preceded by letter(s) indicating gene types within a subgroup (e.g. SCRBQ1, for a gene belonging to the SCRB Class, and to the croquemort type). For historical reasons, in certain families, the third field can also enumerate by letters rather than numerals (e.g. PGRPLA, for gene A of the Long subfamily in the PGRP family).
  • It is recommended that names previously used in the literature or in database submissions be gradually replaced by systematic names, following consultation with the original author. Historical names or names that may be developed eventually to indicate experimentally verified function or orthology can be used as synonyms.
  • Allele names and symbols
    • Superscripts. Alleles at a particular gene are designated by the same name and symbol and are differentiated by distinguishing superscripts. In written text the allele designation may be separated from that of the gene by a hyphen, e.g., white-apricot.
    • Symbols. Allele symbols should be short, preferably no more than three characters long, and cannot contain spaces, superscripts, or subscripts.
    Whenever possible superscript characters should be limited to the following set: a-z A-Z 0-9 - + : . The + symbol is reserved for the wild-type allele. Consecutive allele numbers should be used wherever possible. Greek characters should NOT be used. The character \ is reserved in all gene symbol contexts for species identification. The character / is reserved as a homologue separator in genotypes and cannot be used in allele symbols. In text in which superscripting is not possible, such as ASCII files, superscripted text should be enclosed between the characters [ and ].

Transposons and Transgene Constructs

Generic naturally occurring transposons are symbolized as ends{}, where ends stands for the symbol of a given transposon, such as P for P-element. Doc{}, copia{} and P{} are Drosophila examples, and a similar convention should be used for the mosquito. A defined natural variant of the transposon family can be named by including a symbol for that name inside the brackets. A specific insertion of a given transposon is described by including an additional unique symbol following the brackets. Symbols for constructed transposons, or transgene constructs, must always include a construct symbol, which defines a particular construct. A full transgene construct genotype consists of the source of transposon ends, included genes, construct symbol, and insertion identifier, in the form ends{genes=construct-symbol}. Once defined, ends{construct-symbol} (or less formally, construct-symbol alone) can be used in most circumstances to refer to a specific transgene construct. The symbol for a specific insertion of a given transgene construct has the form ends{construct-symbol}insertion-identifier. Further details are given in the sections that follow. Transposon ends: Pairs of terminal repeats which together form a transposon are symbolized by opposing braces, {}. The source of the transposon ends is indicated outside the braces, at the left end of the string by a symbol derived from the name of the transposon family: P = P-element Ho = Hobo-element He = Hermes-element Ma = Mariner-element Mi = Minos-element PB = piggyBac-element
  • Isolated (non-paired) terminal repeats are indicated with the family symbol followed by 3' or 5', e.g., He5' represents the isolated 5' end of a He{} transposon.
  • Multiple sets of matched transposon ends are indicated by nesting ends{} symbols, e.g., Mi{PB{neo[RT]X[+]}}.
Included genes: A full transgene construct description lists within the braces all functional genes, including non-Anopheles genes such as antibiotic resistance genes, bacterial and phage origins of replication, or the FLP1 recombination target (FRT), separated by spaces. The left-right order of these elements reflect their 5' to 3' order (with respect to the transposon ends) within the construct. If the order of a gene is unknown, it is placed at one end of the list, followed or preceded by a comma.
  • Anopheles gambiae genes. Valid gene symbols are used to name A. gambiae genes. Wild-type alleles of intact genes are indicated by a superscripted '+'. A convenient identifier (used in these examples) is the size of the genomic fragment carrying the wild-type gene. Transgene-construct-borne genes that do not confer wild-type function are given unique allele designations without the preceding '+', e.g., XXXB or YYYD225. Replacement of promoter or other control sequences can be indicated in the allele designation: XXXhs.PP, e.g., for a XXX gene controlled by a heat shock promoter.
  • Species of origin. Species of origin is indicated for non-gambiae Anopheles genes present in transgene constructs as described in 2.3 (see above).
Construct symbol.: Every construct must be assigned a symbol which, in conjunction with the description of the terminal repeats, uniquely describes a transgene construct, for example, He{lacW}, Ho{PDelta2-3}. Symbols must be unique, but should be kept as short as possible.
  • Full genotype. In the full genotype of a transgene construct, the construct symbol is the final entry within the braces, separated from the final gene symbol by the equal sign, e.g., P{lacZP\T.W w+mC ampR ori=lacW} is the full genotype of P{lacW}.
  • Short form and partial genotypes. Once defined, a transgene construct can be referred to by either the transgene symbol, e.g., P{lacW} (or, less formally, lacW), or the symbol plus insertion identifier in most contexts.

Cytogenetic descriptions

Breakpoints should be according to the polytene chromosome maps of Mario Coluzzi and his collaborators. A photographic reproduction of the map, as well as a schematic representation is presented by AnoBase at the URL http://www.anobase.org/Graphic/Cyto_map_graphic.html. Range designations. For the location of a single object (breakpoint of aberration, gene position, site of transposon insertion, etc.) the range is given as "(d1)(S1)-(d2)(S2)", where: d = numbered division (1 to 50) S = lettered subdivision (A to X) If the range encompasses two different numbered divisions (i.e., d1 does not equal d2), then the full designations for both the left end and the right end of the range will be used, e.g., 32A-33A. If the range is within a single numbered division (i.e., d1=d2) but within different subdivisions (i.e., S1 does not equal S2), then the numbered division designation is not repeated to the right of the hyphen, e.g., 32A-D.

Chromosomal aberrations / Inversions

At this time the only chromosomal aberrations concerning anophelines are inversions. The corresponding bibliography is relatively long, and the data are very crucial. Most inversions have been named using a semi-systematic way. The following paragraphs will give instructions for the naming of new inversions, as well as for the "renaming" of the old ones. AnoBase will continue listing the existing names as synonyms, such that the database will be searchable once curation has been initiated. Inversions have the symbol In(nA)m, where n indicates the number of the chromosome involved, A the arm or arms involved and m is a specific designator. In the case of multiple-break intrachromosomal rearrangements, the distinction between inversions and transpositions often becomes ambiguous. An intrachromosomal rearrangement that can be partitioned into a duplicated and a deficient product by exchange with a normal-sequence chromosome is designated a transposition even though it may carry an inverted segment; otherwise, it is designated an inversion. If it is not known whether or not an inversion is paracentric (does not include the centromere) or pericentric (includes the centromere) then the indicator of chromosome arm(s) is omitted, i.e., In(n)m.

Representation of gene, allele and aberration names and symbols in text

  • Italic. Gene, allele, aberration and transposon/transgene-construct names and symbols are italicized in printed text.
  • Non-italic. When a full gene name or gene symbol is used to indicate phenotype, rather than genotype, then that name or symbol is printed in roman (non-italic) type; i.e., white indicates a genotype and white a phenotype.
  • Superscripts and subscripts. In ASCII text the characters [ and ] are used to enclose superscripted characters, and [[ and ]] used to enclose subscripts.
  • Cytogenetic terms. Cytogenetic designations are not italicized except when part of an aberration symbol.
  • Reserved characters. The following characters are reserved for special use in gene, allele, and aberration names and symbols:
\ reserved for use in symbols of genes from species other than A. gambiae { } reserved for use in transposon and transgene construct symbols < > reserved for use in transgene construct names and for cytotype designation in stocks [] reserved for indicating superscripts in ASCII text [[ ]] reserved for indicating subscripts in ASCII text ( ) reserved for use in compound gene names and symbols (e.g., l(1)) and for aberration symbols, and for the indication of ambiguous genotypes ; reserved as a separator of chromosome (chromosome arm) numbers in aberration names and symbols, and to separate markers or aberrations on non-homologous chromosomes in stock genotypes : reserved for use in symbols of defined classes, i.e., transgene constructs, genes encoding special RNAs (tRNAs, snRNAs), fusion genes and mitochondrial genes, and, in stock genotypes, to indicate the association between markers on reciprocol components of translocations, or arms of compound chromosomes.

Gene products

  • Proteins. Protein products that are named for the gene may be symbolically designated in text by the gene symbol, but this symbol is all in roman capital letters.
  • RNAs. There is no convention for symbolically designating RNA products of genes in text. An italicised gene name can also serve to refer to its mRNA where this is unambiguous.

doc.label: Ultra-deep exploration of transcription in Anopheles gambiae
doc.content:
Executive summary

Catastrophic numbers of mosquito-borne disease cases and deaths remain one of the unsolved major health problems in developing countries. Malaria, arboviral diseases and filariasis kill more than one million people and/or debilitate hundreds of millions every year. Management of these diseases relies heavily on the use of insecticides. However, the evolution and spread of insecticide resistance can compromise the effectiveness of control campaigns and disease incidence continues to be extremely high. Approximately 90% of deaths caused by mosquito-borne disease are attributable to malaria in sub-Saharan Africa, where children under the age of five are the primary victims and the mosquito Anopheles gambiae is the major vector. Novel control strategies are urgently needed to combat mosquito-borne diseases, and to meet this challenge we must grasp the biological complexities of the vectors ranging from molecular to population level interactions.

We propose to develop a comprehensive picture of the Anopheles gambiae transcriptome using high-coverage RNA-seq through two discrete, complementary study aims.

Aim 1 will be to characterise the transcripts expressed during development and to utilise this ontogenetic series to drastically improve genome annotation through examining correlated patterns of gene expression. We propose next-generation sequencing of sexed whole-insect transcriptomes at 16 time points spanning from 10- hour old embryos to 20-day old adults. We will identify transcribed features and comprehensively characterize their expression dynamics throughout development.

Aim 2 is to discover additional genes that are induced following physiological stress. To document global transcriptional response to a range of physiological stressors we propose to conduct RNA-seq experiments on females subject to (1) sublethal insecticide exposure and (2) sub-optimal relative humidity (RH), and (3) females post-blood feeding and during vitellogenesis/oogenesis.

The RNA-seq reads from both sets of experiments will be mapped to the PEST and the S molecular form genome sequences to provide an insight into dynamic changes in transcription levels and transcript models will be created to provide a nearly exhaustive catalogue of transcribed features in each sample. Finally, the RNA-seq data will be integrated into Vectorbase as new tracks.

Our study will have a profound impact on the vector research community. Discovery of a complete gene set is a pre-requisite for an understanding of the molecular basis of the development of An. gambiae and its response to physiological and environmental stressors. We expect that deep insight into these processes will allow identification of novel anti-vector targets and will result in effective interventions in disease transmission. Sexed transcriptomes are expected to shed light on mosquito sex determination and sexual differentiation processes that may be targeted in genetic control approaches. A highly improved An. gambiae transcript dataset will also allow efficient implementation of comparative methods to the annotation of additional Anopheles genomes that are currently in a sequencing pipeline. Further, it will be highly informative for improvement of annotations of the already sequenced culicine, sandfly, tsetse fly and other vectors genomes.

doc.label: RAD Sequencing of SNPs in the Ixodes scapularis (Lyme Disease Tick) Genome:  Toward an Integrated Genetic and Physical Map
doc.content:
EXECUTIVE SUMMARY:

Disease Vectors: This project will generate novel genomic and biological resources made publically available through VectorBase (VB) (Lawson et al., 2009) and Purdue University to accelerate research on the Lyme disease tick, Ixodes scapularis. More broadly, it will support genome-driven research in multiple tick and mite vectors of disease.

Project Description: This Driving Biological Project (DBP) addresses the current lack of a high-quality genomic sequence for a tick vector of disease that is fully integrated with genetic and physical maps. This is one of the greatest impediments to the translation of genome data into solutions for tick-borne disease control. The advent of high throughput sequencing (HTS) technologies provides the first realistic opportunity to overcome this hurdle. We focus our attention on the Lyme disease tick, I. scapularis, which is the most important arthropod vector of human disease in North America. Ixodes scapularis is the only tick for which a genome assembly is available, a valuable resource that our research will exploit and then improve for the scientific community, as we develop new genetic resources for tick and mite research. We propose the first use of genome-wide single nucleotide polymorphism (SNP) discovery in I. scapularis in order to (1) create the first densely populated tick genetic map, (2) launch the first population genomics studies for any tick species, and (3) produce an integrated sequence, genetic and physical map of the I. scapularis genome. We will utilize the cost-effective Restriction-Site-Associated DNA sequencing (RADseq) technique (Miller et al., 2007a) featuring the Illumina sequencing platform for SNP discovery. SNPs are the most abundant genetic markers that, when paired with HTS approaches, provide novel opportunities for vastly expanding genome resources needed to address central genetic and evolutionary questions underlying tick and mite vector biology. The genomic data and resources proposed on this DBP are shown in Table 1.

Table 1. Summary of proposed I. scapularis genomic data & biological resources
Genomic Data Number Database Aim
Illumina reads Billions SRA 1, 2
SNP markers Thousands VB/dbSNP 1, 2
Genetic maps 1-2 (W x W, W x I maps) VB 1
FISH images/physical map ~ 100 mapped BAC clones/one map VB 3
Biological Resources Number Institution Aim
I. scapularis colonies ≤ 10 (CT, GA, IN, MA, MD, MN, SC, WI, ON, QU) Purdue, MR4 1, 2
F1 Mapping Populations 1-2 (W x W, W x I crosses) Purdue, MR4 1
BAC, Bacterial Artificial Chromosome; dbSNP, SNP database; I, Indiana strain; MR4; NIH Malaria Research Repository; ON, Ontario; QU, Quebec; SRA, Short Read Archive; W, Wikel strain

Impact on VB and Scientific Communities: We anticipate the following impact on the scientific communities served by VB. Firstly, the project will provide for an improved I. scapularis genome assembly that will facilitate expanded research on this vector and underpin genome initiatives for other tick and mite vectors. Secondly, project resources will facilitate much needed population gemomics research (e.g., genotyping and association mapping) on I. scapularis. This DBP will enable our team to make progress toward our long-term goal of generating the first high-density linkage map for I. scapularis. The laboratory lines we establish on this project will be assessed for quantifiable traits such as host preference and vector competence and used to create mapping populations to map genes influencing these traits. Lastly, our proposed integrated sequence, genetic and physical map will provide a community tool for analysis of genome organization among I. scapularis populations, and comparative analyses between acarine species.

doc.label: Release VB_2012-10
doc.content:
Overview

We are pleased to announce the October release of VectorBase (VB-2012-10). Highlights of the October release of VectorBase (VB-2012-10) include:

  • Presites for the genomes of the sandflies: Phlebotomus papatasi and Lutzomyia longipalpis
  • New gene set for Anopheles gambiae (AgamP3.7)
  • Updated variation databases for Anopheles gambiae

Additionally, we have just completed a preview of the newly-designed, next generation VectorBase website. We invite you to try it out and provide constructive feedback on it. Nearly all of the content in the VB-2012-10 release is present in the preview site and available through a redesigned tab-driven navigation system. Details regarding this preview can be found below.

Genomes

VectorBase is please to release two pre-sites for Phlebotomus papatasi and Lutzomyia longipalpis. Both of these have been released in GenBank and details can be found below.

Fully released genomes, with gene predictions

Aedes aegypti Liverpool AaegL1 AaegL1.3 AAGE02000000
Anopheles gambiae PEST AgamP3 AgamP3.7 AAAB01000000
Culex quinquefasciatus JHB CpipJ1 CpipJ1.3 AAWU01000000
Ixodes scapularis Wikel IscaW1 IscaW1.2 ABJB01000000

Rhodnius prolixus CDC RproC1 ACPB00000000 Repeats, ESTs, RNA-seq and protein similarities - GenScan ab initio predictions and EST-build genes.
Glossina morsitansYale GmorY1 - Repeats, RNA-seq (via BAM files) - EST-build genes, SNAP ab initio predictions, MAKER gene predictions.
Anopheles darlingi AdarC1 ADMH00000000 Repeats, ENA and UniProtKB annotation.
Anopheles stephensi Indian Wild Type AsteI1 - Repeats, EST-build genes, SNAP ab initio predictions, MAKER gene predictions.

An. gambiae gene set AgamP3.7

The An. gambiae gene set has had a major update bringing in novel predictions and model corrections from both VectorBase staff (University of New Mexico/Harvard University) and community submissions. Over 1200 predictions have been updated as well as150 new loci, 87 merge events (>=2 canonical models now modeled by a single prediction) and 59 split events (single canonical model now modeled by >=2 predictions),

Variation Data

Variation data for two studies describing mapping of insecticide resistance in Africa have been included in this release. The studies are described in

  • Weetman, David, Wilding, Craig, Steen, Keith, Pinto, J. and Donnelly, Martin (2011) 'Gene Flow-Dependent Genomic Divergence Between Anopheles gambiae M and S Forms'. Molecular Biology and Evolution, Vol 29, Issue 1, pp. 279-291. (doi: 10.1093/molbev/msr199)
  • Weetman, David, Wilding, Craig, Steen, Keith, Morgan, John, Simard, Frederic and Donnelly, Martin (2010) 'Association Mapping of Insecticide Resistance in Wild Anopheles gambiae Populations: Major Variants Identified in a Low-Linkage Disequilbrium Genome'. PLoS ONE, Vol 5, Issue 10, e13140. (doi:10.1371/journal.pone.0013140)

These samples were typed using a Goldengate microarray platform, on a variety of samples from different geographical locations in Africa.
Population Location Collection_year Total_samples
Yaounde Cameroon 2006 735
Tororo Uganda 2008 214
Dodowa Ghana 2006 802
Antula Guinea-Bissau 1993 80

For some loci a large number of individuals may be noted next to the "resequencing" tag in the genetic variation data display section. This tag normally allows users to access sequence coverage data for the regions for all of the strains indicated, but as these samples were genotyped on a microarray chip this coverage data is not available. We are investigating ways to make the normal resequencing display functionality available.

Expression Data

A new dataset for An. gambiae has been added:

  • Desiccation stress, Wang et al. 2011

Ontologies

VectorBase supports four ontologies developed by IMBB with members of the research community. These are available for browsing and download.

Ontology Version Description
MIRO 2.0 An ontology to describe mosquito populations, methods and mechanisms that are used to identify/monitor insecticide resistance.

IDOMAL 1.2.4 An ontology to describe all aspects of malaria. Clinical data, epidemiological data, biological data concerning vertebrate hosts, vectors and parasites as well as interventions and attempts to control the disease.

Ontology browser

The Controlled Vocabulary/Ontology browser has been upgraded. Most noteworthy changes:

  • it is now possible to search for terms using synonyms
  • term synonyms are now listed along with the rest of the term's details
  • OBO flat files can be downloaded by using the links on the main page of the CV browser

Preview of newly designed website

The beta version of the website can be accessed at https://preview.vectorbase.org. To help you get acclimated, here are five specific changes for review (among many):

  • We have redesigned the homepage to highlight data, tools and resources, FAQs and community interactions. We also anticipate user-focused customization (e.g., accessing previous analyses) in later versions of this site.
  • The BLAST tool has been improved based on prior feedback It is available at: https://preview.vectorbase.org/blast and under the “Tools” tab.
  • The search box in the upper right corner of all VectorBase pages can access a new unified search framework. All queries are filterable.
  • We have extended the organisms page (https://preview.vectorbase.org/organisms) and species pages (e.g. https://preview.vectorbase.org/organisms/anopheles-gambiae). This has allowed us to group current and emerging genomes in a scalable manner while also highlighting and archiving strain, assembly and gene build history.
  • The old help pages/wiki have been reallocated into new content under “About”, “Help”, and “Community” tabs to consolidate these important documents into a single site and to facilitate search access (see #2 above).
We are interested in feedback about these changes using the Contact Us page or mail the the helpdesk.

Known issues

Biomart has not yet been updated with the new genomes; we anticpate this being released within a week.

Please report any problems to the helpdesk.

doc.label: VectorBase Hands-on  Workshop
doc.content:
Thursday and Friday, January 31st and February 1st, 2013

1040 Fernwood Rd, Bethesda, Maryland

Instructors

Gloria I. Giraldo-Calderón and Andrew Sheehan (University of Notre Dame)

Dan Lawson (European Molecular Biology Laboratory, EMBL - European Bioinformatics Institute, EBI)

About the VectorBase Hands-on Workshop

A hands-on workshop will be held at the NIH campus. The goal of the workshop is to present a brief overview of the NEW VectorBase website and offer a training and data analysis opportunity to users. This two-day event will comprise a mixture of lectures and hands-on practical sessions where users can discuss their own data sets/problems with the instructors and fellow attendees. The instructors will be vector bioinformaticians and biologists. A basic knowledge of how to use either Artemis or Apollo for gene annotation is preferred.

Computer and Internet Access

The training room provides 15 computers for participants to use during the workshop. You are encouraged to bring your own laptop to use. If bringing your own laptop, please make sure to have the latest version of Java, Apollo and Artemis installed and arrive at 8:30 a.m in order to get access to the NIH-airnet.

Registration

The workshop is free of charge, but seating is limited to 30 people. Please register early to ensure a seat. To register, please contact Karlynn Noble at karlynn.noble@nih.gov. You will need to provide your name, phone number, email address, organization. Please also include your 1) research interest detailing your aims, hypotheses, research questions, gene or gene family of interest; 2) data type you work with or would like to work with, e.g. RNA-seq, re-sequencing, SNP calls and; 3) data status, e.g. raw, processed or ready for submission (200 words maximum).

Agenda (subject to change)

Thursday, January 31st, 2013

9:00 am – 12:00 pm

VectorBase (NEW) website navigation

Finding, visualizing and exporting data:
  • Available data types: VectorBase data and your own or other external data sets
  • Search
  • Browsing genomes: Compara and Variation tool
  • BioMart
  • Ontology Browser
  • Population biology browser (BETA)
How to contribute to VectorBase and get community visibility for your research work?
  • Using HMMER versus BLAST to find homologs
  • Using Artemis and Apollo for manual annotation

12:00 – 1:00 pm Lunch (on your own)

1:00 – 4:00 pm

  • Submitting your gene models to VectorBase using the Community Annotation Portal (CAP)
  • Submitting gene expression data, genome browser tracks, and etc.
  • Submitting gene metadata (papers, gene names and symbols)

Invited speaker: To be confirmed.

A big picture ”all genes, all factors” analysis for expression data
  • Expression Browser
  • Expression Maps

Friday, February 1st, 2013

9:00 am – 12:00 pm

Be a VectorBase “power user”
  • How to make the best use of your data, VectorBase data, tools and resources to analyze and publish your research?
  • Hands on session with attendees’ datasets.
  • Opportunity to interact with other VectorBase bioinformaticians and biologists using conference call.

NOTE: You are strongly encouraged to bring your own data for all the sessions to make the best out of the hands-on sessions of each of the workshop topics.

doc.label: Gene trees
doc.content:
VectorBase gene trees are generated by the Gene Orthology/Paralogy prediction method pipeline. Genetrees aim to represent the evolutionary history of gene families, i.e. genes that diverged from a common ancestor. Homologies in VectorBase are determined from gene trees. Gene trees are constructed using the longest protein for every gene in every species in VectorBase. The display shows the maximum likelihood phylogenetic tree representing the evolutionary history of gene families. These trees reconciled with their species tree, generated by TreeBeST, have their internal nodes annotated for duplication or speciation events.

Key to Gene tree visualisation

: The gene of interest is highlighted in red. Within-species paralogues are blue. Blue squares represent speciation nodes. Red squares represent duplications nodes. Another class of node, ambiguous, is shown as a lighter blue square. Taxonomy IDs refer to the NCBI Taxonomy Browser. Node pop-up menus (upon clicking on a node) correspond to the relevant taxon and contain links to Multi-species view, alignments and more. Multiple alignment of the peptides (green bars) was made using MUSCLE. Green shows areas of amino acid alignment, white areas are gaps in the alignment. Click on a node to expand a collapsed set of branches into a full tree. The consensus amino acid alignment corresponds to the consensus residues in the collapsed node, and will be expanded when the tree is expanded. Use Configure this page to customise the tree. Colouring by clade can be removed.

doc.label: Stop by our booth at the ASTMH 61st Annual meeting!
doc.content:
Dear VectorBase users,

Like last year we are going to have a booth at the Annual Meeting of the American Society of Tropical Medicine and Hygiene (ASTMH), which takes place this year in Atlanta, Georgia, USA, November 11-15, 2012.

Our booth (#322) will be open from Nov 11 to Nov 14, please stop by and tell us what do you think of our NEW web site, https://preview.vectorbase.org, our current data sets, tools and resources or what new things in these areas you would like to see in our website.

We'll be running a draw with VectorBase T-shirts and mugs as prizes. All you have to do is help us improve VectorBase! You could tell us about the genes you have been working on so that we can associate gene names and publications, give functional description to a gene you work with or tell us where searches on the new website don't give the answers you expect. This is a chance to get VectorBase to reflect data from your work. We look forward to seeing you all in Atlanta!"

We will also have information related with our outreach activities for year 2013 including:

  • Hands-on workshop at NIH campus, Bethesda, Maryland, January 31 and February 2nd (more info and agenda)
  • 7th Annual Arthropod Genomics Symposium and VectorBase Workshop at Notre Dame University, Notre Dame, Indiana, June 13-16.

You are also cordially invited to stop by the poster “Developing ontologies for Vectors and Vector-Borne Diseases” (Abstract 70), on Monday, Nov 12, Session A, 12:00-1:45 pm., whose authors are part of the VectorBase team.

Next year we will also be hosting the genomes of the 16 Anopheles cluster project. A public forum at ASTMH regarding the status of the project will be held on Monday, Nov 12, 12:30-1:30 p.m, Hilton Room 211, all are welcome. https://preview.vectorbase.org/anopheles-cluster-meeting-astmh

Not going to ASTMH this year? Contact info@vectorbase.org for comments, suggestions, questions or feedback.

Best,

The VectorBase team.

Overview

Highlights of the April release of VectorBase (VB-2012-04) include:

  • Entrez-style search box. Our site search now automatically queries multiple domains and allows one click access to search results across VectorBase data.
  • New gene patches. Aedes, Culex and Ixodes gene sets have all been updated with community-supplied gene improvements.
  • Updated genome browser. VectorBase now runs e! version 66.

Genomes

Patches to the following species to incorporate community gene models:

  • Aedes aegypti (AaegL1.3)
  • Culex quinquefasciatus (CpipJ1.3)
  • Ixodes scapularis (IscaW1.2)

As a result of the gene set patchings, the Compara protein homologies and BioMart have been updated.

Updated Rhodnius prolixus gene build fixing partially overlapping transcripts problem.

doc.label: Release VB_2012-02
doc.content:
Overview

Please note that we did not make the release scheduled for December 2011. This was due to stability issues with the new hardware which is now hosting the VectorBase website. There will be an additional release in March 2012 to accommodate some genome annotation updates. The regular two-monthly release cycle will continue from May 2012.

Highlights of the February release of VectorBase (VB-2012-02) include:

  • Improved front-page search: genomes, ontologies, expression data and population data are now searchable.
  • Simplified, enhanced new graphical interface to our expression maps.

Genomes

No new genomic data has been released or updated.

Fully released genomes, with gene predictions

Species Assembly Gene set GenBank WGS

Pediculus humanus USDA PhumU1 PhumU1.2 AAZO01000000

Species Assembly GenBank WGS Data available

Anopheles gambiae S AgamS1 ABKQ00000000 Repeats, ESTs
